services.name: GitHub
services.text: Version control and collaboration for code

services.name: Vercel
services.text: Usually ship hobby projects and a few production apps to vercel.

services.name: Netlify
services.text: I ship some client sites here, especially when I want to easily integerate with netlify-cms

services.name: Render
services.text: To be fair, I haven't deployed here yet, but I plan to for the next hobby project.

tech.name: React
tech.text: My choice and expertise for UI framework

tech.name: Sass
tech.text: For more traditional sites, scaling CSS with Sass is a breeze

tech.name: Styled components
tech.text: A decent css-in-js solution for web apps, but I like other flavors of css-in-js too

tech.name: Testing Library
tech.text: I use this for testing React components

tech.name: Cypress
tech.text: Handy client for end to end tests

tech.name: Apollo
tech.text: Prod ready GraphQL client for web apps

tech.name: GraphQL
tech.text: A great option for typed APIs unless you already have one in REST

tech.name: Chakra-UI
tech.text: My current favorite react UI kit

tech.name: Postgres
tech.text: Database of choice for most side projects (and I use it at work)

tech.name: NextJS
tech.text: The ideal way to get a React site up, running, and deployed quickly.

tech.name: Prisma
tech.text: Database ORM for JS-land. I usually use Postgres or sqlite as the database.

tech.name: TypeScript
tech.text: I cannot go back to vanilla JavaScript.

tech.name: Jest
tech.text: A little bloated but one stop shop for testing.

tech.name: Prettier
tech.text: arguably one of my top 5 of tools that has come out in the past 10 years.

tech.name: Postcss
tech.text: Mostly used these days to get autoprefixer and tailwind running.

tech.name: Tailwindcss
tech.text: I often use tailwind for hobby projects or small clients. Have yet to use it for a major work project but I would entertain it.

tech.name: Heroicons
tech.text: Hands down easiest and cleanest icons to quickly use in Figma designs and import into code

tech.name: Docker
tech.text: I'm not a pro yet but for some easy database setup, I can rely on docker

desktop apps.name: Chrome
desktop apps.text: Sometimes I try to swap to FireFox or Brave browser, but I'm so used to Chrome at this point

desktop apps.name: Raycast
desktop apps.text: Mac OS spotlight on steriods. My favorite app for quickly searching and opening files, apps, and more. Replaced Alfred instant I found it. The plugin/extension DX is so approachable, given my skillset.

desktop apps.name: iTerm2
desktop apps.text: A slight step above default terminal (mainly for split pane management), but I'm not a power user

desktop apps.name: Rectangles
desktop apps.text: Hotkeys for resizing and moving apps between monitors

desktop apps.name: Figma
desktop apps.text: Tool of choice for UI designs. Previously was using Sketch (and photoshop long ago) but Figma is just so much better.

desktop apps.name: GitHub Desktop
desktop apps.text: I can use git cli, but like to have a gui for quick commits and visualizing diffs faster

desktop apps.name: Spotify
desktop apps.text: I always feel more productive with music to code to

desktop apps.name: Slack
desktop apps.text: Work communication and a few support channels

desktop apps.name: Discord
desktop apps.text: Messaging my social circle, joining tech communities, and gaming

home office.name: Custom PC
home office.text: GTX 2060 GPU, Intel Core i7-9700k 3.6ghz CPU, 16gb DDR4 RAM, 3tb SSD/HDD, NZXT Kraken AIO, NZXT H510 matte black case

home office.name: Custom 60% mechnical keyboard
home office.text: Lubed zealios zilent switches, brass plate, tofu60 case, lubed stabs. I finally built a fully custom keyboard and already thinking about the next build

home office.name: Sony WH1000XM4 headphones
home office.text: A quiet environment (or consistent music) is a must for my focus

home office.name: Autonomous ErgoChair 2
home office.text: Switching from a 'gamer' chair to a proper office chair was a nice step up, but there are still some features I wish the chair had

home office.name: Jarvis standing desk legs + custom built pine wood desktop
home office.text: In 2019, though I wasn't 100% WFH, I commited to getting a proper desk set up for home, so I built a wood desktop and bought motorized standing desk legs from Fully. I don't stand as much as I should, but it's nice to have available when I need it.

home office.name: Phillips hue light bars
home office.text: I need some lighting to offset the bright screens, and I like being able to control these from Raycast or other devices

home office.name: Google Home WiFi
home office.text: For consistent wifi throughout the living quarters.

home office.name: Google Pixel phone
home office.text: I appreciate the vanilla-ish Android experience of Pixels, having come from an iPhone before. I use the google ecosystem so Android was a logical switch.

home office.name: Amazon Nest security camera
home office.text: For keeping an eye on things
